ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Jessica is a fantastic instructor and is very approachable. She is very helpful with the course projects and is very supportive. She is very understanding and has a genuine character that makes the course even more enjoyable.
Jessica is extremely supportive of her students. She goes above and beyond to send you resources she thinks my be helpful and to answer any questions you may have.

Unfortunately I could only go on one of the two field trips, but the one I went on was informative and I'm glad I went. Jessica is a fantastic professor. I took her Land Use Seminar in the fall, and was exited to take another course with her this spring. She is accessible, patient, kind, and very clear in her instruction. If you're interesting in land use planning, take a class with her!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Jessica is very flexible and cares that everyone gets what they want out of this course. She is aware that everyone would like to have a project that they can discuss at interviews etc. so she was very flexible in making the project work for everyone. I got to work on the project that I was most interested in, with a great client, and semester ran smoothly.
Jessica is one of the best professors- organized, clear, direct, and very responsive. This class was really helpful and well put together!

The best part of the course was the professional environment and autonomy given to the students. It was designed in a very intelligent way...not sure how the instructor managed the various projects given the variety of demands from students and the projects themselves. However, I was impressed with the attention given. The course included a well thought out lecture series, with great outside speakers and contributors.
Working on client projects and the field trips
The project work - very helpful in learning more about topics.
The ability to work with a client to solve a real problem
A significant amount of learning came from working directly with clients during the project portion of the course

The professor is flexible and the projects are often on the leading edge of research in certain areas. Therefore you have a lot of freedom to go where to the project takes you as long as the client is in agreement.
The projects and the field trips both provide interaction with communities and exposure to real world land use issues. It's a very practical course and has a wide variety of project options.

Jessica is a great professor! The whole point of the course is the clinical project, so I'd say that's the best aspect. It gives you real, hands-on experience with a client, which is a nice break from regular classroom work.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I really liked this course but maybe the field trips could be planned more thoroughly in advance. I really wanted to attend one of the field trips but it was moved around a few times and by that time I had agreed to something else.
Work more closely with the client to clarify exactly what is needed upfront to save time during the semester debating the deliverable
Some clients are not always very responsive. This is understandable but sometimes concerning. Perhaps the clients could agree to a check-in at a frequency that works for them.
Nothing needs improvement.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Very effective, no change recommended.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am interested in urban water resource management, so this class was really helpful in bringing the theory of some of my other classes to a real life, client-based project. I would love to see more classes like Jessica's offered at FES!
Learning land use concepts is a good addition to my main studies.
I am interested in renewable energy development, so this provided me a perspective on siting and land use issues with large renewable energy projects.

I'm studying conservation, but I think it's also important to understand basic land use history, land use planning and development. It serves as a background framework for understanding conservation as well.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to take another clinic course and there were some great renewable energy projects.
I wanted to have some real life experience with land use and urban water management.

The course offered a capstone project that was perfectly aligned with my academic focus and interests in oil and gas. Not having to create a project from scratch saved a lot of time. Additionally, the project required someone with a strong marketing and branding background to see the project to launch. My combination of skills and background allowed me to focus on creating high-level content and a high-quality finished product, rather than spend the time acquiring new skills for the sake of the exercise, which I believe served quite well, the students and professors who put in valuable time before me.
Wanted to work on the client project and Jessica is a great instructor.
Did not have a background in land use, and this was an opportunity to gain more knowledge about land use challenges and policies.
To learn more about how communities can be engaged in the siting of large renewable energy projects.
I am interested in land use and urban planning. This course provides very practical skills and related experience.

I really enjoyed Jessica's fall course. I thought having some hands-on clinical experience would be a good idea, and I also thought that diving a little deeper into land use planning would serve as a nice compliment to my interest in land conservation.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes! Jessica was fantastic and the project helped bring together my interest in municipal government, land use management, and water.
Exceeded expectations. Glad I took this course.
Yes
Yes
Yes. The workshop-based lectures were interesting and helpful, and the skills learned on the fly while carrying out the client project were very useful.
Definitely. I'm sure it depends on which project you are working on, but if you pick a project carefully, then you will get a lot out of the course.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Working on the client project was conducive for group work. You learn teamwork and project management skills in addition to gaining subject matter expertise.
We were able to accomplish more than if it had just been one person.

We didn't have group work, per se, but each student had a semester long clinical project which was the foundation of our learning in the course. I enjoyed my project a lot. I had a great supervisor, and I learned a lot.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would suggest students think about what they hope to get out of the course and select a project based off of those interests and skills. I would also suggest that students set clear boundaries with their client at the beginning of the semester. If things are at all unclear, it becomes difficult to deliver a true "final product" at the end of the semester.

Jessica is a great person to know, and work with. No matter your interests and direction, I recommend taking her course. We often meet people who have amazing qualities about them (work ethic, integrity, tact, grace, etc.) that have little to do with the "job", and the experience of being with that person or working with that person transcends the task, and ends up being more valuable in the long-run. Jessica has that unique quality about her, I learned more from her 'the professional' than I did the course - which is not something advertised on the syllabus!
If you're excited about a client project take this course. Jessica is great and the field trips are informative and fun.
If you are interested in learning about land use planning and happy to take a class where the assignments center on a project for a partner organization, that you will enjoy this course.
Jessica is a great professor, and if you want more exposure to land use with the opportunity to work on a wide array of interesting projects you should take this course.

Jessica is great a resource and a good person to know. As long as you pick a project applicable to your interests and one you are excited about, you will have a great experience. It isn't an overly time-consuming class but you can get a lot out of it.

Budget your time wisely! It's easy to push off project work since the final deliverable isn't due until the last day of the semester, and class only meets once a week for an hour or so. There isn't much to hold you accountable, so it's easy to procrastinate. But then you might find yourself scrambling to complete everything in a timely manner as well as produce something with good quality.
